author: Jeronimo Backes
title: Wallet Name System (WNS)
description: Any cryptocurrency user should be able to send funds to human readable names instead of wallet addresses, and know if recipient is legit

assessments.note: its not clear this is a developer experience proposal. Should possibly be in the DApps and integrations fund.
a standardized approach to human readable addresses would improve the development experience as well as the user experience.

There is no explanation of how this project will simplify development on Cardano. It makes sending tokens/ADA easier, but that is not the primary goal of the challenge. Using WNS in applications adds a feature, but it does not really make the development easier.

Great idea to improve general user friendlyness of wallets. It simplifies long strings of address code into human readable wallet names. So a user would be able to access a private addressbook and select a name as a recipient. Pretty much the same idea as selecting a name instead of a bank address while homebanking. A system like this would add to general accessability. The proposal is a better fit for the Metadata challenge. A wallet name is metadata.

This proposal is a good idea for a great implementation of a backend service that communicate with the cardano blockchain and add value for the cardano wallet owners.  The proposal clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem. However the objective of the proposal is based only on back-end system and not for front-end system, so I think it's a god starting point for developers and for stake pool owner that can be run these services for the final users. I think there is a possible security concerns related to the owner wallet, but it's important to deep dive on the detailed process.

The proposal is well detailed and displays some technical understanding of the requirements. The proposer participated in community discussion. The proposer seems qualified and motivated but I would like to see some additional team members with blockchain experience. The NTF-DAO has a similar project and I think I would prefer to see that team working on this problem with their technical expertise and vision of standardization.

Die angeführten Kenntnisse sind überzeugend und die Beschreibung im Video lässt ebenfalls auf hohes Fachwissen schliessen. Die Umsetzung als Open-Source Projekt ist ebenfalls ein positiver Aspekt. Die Kooperation und Weiternutzung des Projekt-Ergenisses wird dadurch vereinfacht.

The proposer's experience is very relevant as there is 20+ years as a software developer stated. It is not entirely clear if the proposer is intending to develop this on his own or with the help of a team. The requested fund only reflects a wage of software developer pegged to US standards. Which implies that the intent is to indeed develop this solo, however in the comments section it is stated that the author owns a software company. If it is the case that the intent is that this company develops it, it should be included in the proposal. It also raises the question as to how the initial server would be paid for.

The proposal team is completed skilled and have a good technical knowledge, so in my opinion will able to make surely a good pilot . In relation to the possible success of the initiative, I think that idea functionality is useful, so there are a lot of possibilities for the adoption by the community. Further I think it's important to improve details about the process related to the functionality and with more detailed plan
This proposal doesn't include detail describe on team, team skills, or team experience. Therefore rendering the project unfeasible.
Project is feasible, though it not clear it addresses the challenge. Note there are similar proposals such as the one by NFT-DAO (in both fund 4 and fund5)
assessments.reply: Proposal clearly states this is a project aimed at software developers.

assessments.note: The proposer pays themselves a salary and proposes launching within 5 months. code and progress will be viewable on github. We should be able to assess the success of the project using these factors.

There are almost no milestones and KPIs. The only metric given are commits on github. It is unclear how this metric can be used to measure project progress and solution adoption. The self-assessment checklist also stated that success was specified after 3, 6 and 12 months. There is nothing of this in the proposal. The only information that can be used for this evaluation criterion is the listed development activities.

The proposal contains a lot of information and something audiovisual like an explanatory video is always a plus. Yet there were still some aspects not entirely clear. 
If a constraint is imposed on a transaction. Would that transaction bounce or would it pass? 
How would a 'scam address' be determined? What would stop competition from flagging eachother? 
How would the 'minimum of 1 ADA per registration' scale towards the future?

The proposer provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with poor milestones and a high level time horizon. I miss in this area that the proposer has not mentioned possible difficulties and market competitor. I think that they require to do a business plan, especially related to revenues of the services
assessments.reply: This is a backend solution for developers who want to use it. Market competition and business plans are out of scope (developers who build end-user applications using this will have to worry about that)

solution: To build a decentralized network that maps names and other information to wallet addresses, much like the internet's DNS but for wallets.
experience: Tech Lead with 20+ years of software development experience, masters degree in computer science, creator of multiple open-source projects.
